cbeust wrote:
> 
> 
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> 
>  > The design /is/ the point of the discussion.
> 
> No, it is *a* point of discussion.  It's healthy to ask the original
> poster if this design is really necessary, but if they say "yes", then
> we should just move on to solving their problem and not patronize them
> on how pure their architecture is.

Cedric, I don't know whether you actually read the entire discussion, 
but /not once/ did I criticize the design of the production code. What I 
told the OP a few times was that he was /misusing/ inheritance of test 
case classes in JUnit, and it took him a while to see that I might have 
a point worth worrying about. Not once did I suggest his production code 
design was bad. Not once. All I said was that inheriting test case 
classes in JUnit without wanting to inherit the test methods was silly 
and that he could have the benefit of sharing test fixture data without 
inadvertently sharing test methods.

> In real life, faulty or imperfect designs are the norm.

Cedric, you just said in the previous paragraph that I shouldn't 
patronize. Now you patronize me. Maybe your message carries less 
strength that way. :)

> If a framework forces you to change your design to be useful, you can
> bet that most companies will keep their design and choose another
> framework.

I can also bet that a large segment of the population will fork over a 
bunch of money to see the latest Will Smith film, but that doesn't make 
it a good film. Popular, yes; good, not necessarily.
